protocol_name: Dog Bite on Human - General Protocol

infection_risk.why_dangerous: Dog bites often create crushing injuries with tissue damage. Larger wounds increase infection risk. Bacteria from dog's mouth can cause serious infections.

immediate_actions.action: For bleeding wounds: Apply firm pressure with clean cloth
Wash wound thoroughly with soap and water
immediate_actions.note: Longer washing time than other injuries due to bacteria load

mandatory_if: Wounds on face, hands, feet, or genitals
Bites from stray or unknown dogs
Wound is gaping or needs stitches

tetanus.required_if: Last shot >5 years ago OR unknown history

rabies_assessment.risk_level: Variable - depends heavily on dog status
questions_to_answer: Is dog vaccinated against rabies (verify records)?
Can dog be observed for 10 days?
pep_required_if: Dog showing abnormal behavior (aggression, lethargy, paralysis, drooling)
Dog cannot be confined for observation
Dog dies or becomes ill during observation period
rabies_assessment.note: Rabies is almost always fatal once symptoms appear - do not delay if ANY doubt about dog's status

monitoring.action_if_signs: Seek medical attention same day - infection developing

children.note: Children more likely to have face/neck bites

large_dogs.note: Can cause severe crushing injuries and fractures

what_not_to_do: DO NOT close wound with tape/glue (let medical professional decide)
DO NOT apply ice directly to wound
DO NOT assume minor wounds are safe

legal_considerations.documentation: Take photos, record dog owner information, witness names
legal_considerations.insurance: May need for medical bills or liability

full_protocol_text: Dog bites carry 15-20% infection risk. Bacteria include Pasteurella, Staph, Strep, and Capnocytophaga. Dog bites often cause crushing injuries with tissue damage. IMMEDIATE ACTION: If bleeding, apply firm pressure for 10-15 minutes. Wash wound thoroughly with soap and water for 15-20 minutes (longer than typical wounds). Rinse for 5 minutes. Apply antibiotic ointment, cover with sterile bandage, elevate if possible. SEEK MEDICAL ATTENTION within 8-12 hours for deep punctures, crushing injuries, face/hand/foot bites, stray dogs, or wounds needing stitches. Antibiotics (Amoxicillin-clavulanate) often prescribed for high-risk bites. CRITICAL: Assess rabies risk - verify dog's vaccination, observe for 10 days if owned. Rabies PEP required if stray, unknown vaccination, abnormal behavior, or cannot observe. Monitor 14 days for infection signs: spreading redness, swelling, pus, fever, red streaks. Report to animal control. Face bites always require immediate care.
